item.title: Malware Lab
item.author: matteratze@gmail.com (Cambie ツ)
item.description:
One of the key aspects of analyzing malware is having a safe environment in which we can detonate malware without any danger. In this guide we’ll set up our own lab using qemu/kvm stack.

Let’s start with the basics.

What is KVM, Qemu and libvirt ?

These three components are system tools, services or features that enable us to virtualize.

  • KVM (Kernel-based Virtual Machine) is an open source virtualization technology for Linux OS. It allows Linux to function as a hypervisor that runs multiple, isolated VMs.
  • Qemu (Quick Emulator) is a generic and open source machine emulator and virtualizer. The most common use is for System Emulation, where it provides hardware such as Disk, network and USB. Even though the CPU can be fully emulated, it may work with a hypervisor like KVM to allow the guest to run directly on the host CPU.
  • libvirt is an opensource API, daemon and management tool for managing platform virtualization. It can be used to manage KVM, Xen, VM-Ware, Qemu, etc. APIs are consumed by client tools for provisioning and managing VMs.

why qemu?

In my experience qemu is insanely fast and incredibly reliable when it comes to virtualization.

Whoami?

My name is Cambie. I’m the creator and maintainer of the Malbian Project: A Simple & Lightweight debian-based GNU/Linux distribution focused on Malware Analysis and Reverse Engineering.

I’m also a Cybersecurity enthusiast with love and passion for GNU/Linux and Low level code!

I made this blog in order to keep track of my progress while also providing content related to Malware Analysis, RE and Hacking. Here you’ll find documentation, writeups and walkthroughs about certain challenges, samples or simply raw information.

item.title: The Malbian Project
item.author: matteratze@gmail.com (Cambie ツ)
item.description:
Malbian is a debian-based GNU/Linux distribution focusing on Malware Analysis and Reverse Engineering. This means that this distribution is shipped with tools to aid the analyst in a positive way.

Malbian uses the Xfce Desktop Environment even though there’s going to be an extra light-weight ISO with dwm (dynamic window manager) from Suckless which will be the main flavor of the distribution. But don’t worry, XFCE4 ISO will continue to be maintained by me.
